49 Years Ago: Dave Davies Knocked Out By Bandmate During Kinks Show

by Ken Kelley May 25, 2014 12:00 PM

While Kiss have made recent headlines for their inter-band squabbles, it all seems a little on the trivial side compared to what the Kinks have endured. Performing at Cardiff’s Capital Theatre in 1965, high-running tensions among band members came to a head while the group was on stage 49 years ago this month.

As told by Kinks member Ray Davies, Kinks drummer Mick Avory was looking to exact a little revenge on Davies’ brother Dave, who had kicked over Avory’s drum set in retaliation for an alcohol-fuelled fight the night before.

The Kinks had performed just two songs at the Capital Theatre when Dave Davies told Avory, “Why don’t you get your c— out and play the snare with it? It’ll probably sound better.”

Needless to say, Avory did not take Davies suggestion too kindly. When the dust between the two settled, Davies was laying on the stage unconscious while Avory fled the concert hall, convinced he had killed his band mate. Davies was rushed to Cardiff Royal Infirmary and received 16 stitches.

When the police caught up with The Kinks drummer (who was in hiding), he denied the whole thing happened. The cops cleverly replied however, that they had the entire audience as witnesses to what went down on stage.

Dave Davies ended up dropping all charges against Avory and somehow, against all odds, relations in the band were smoothed over. The same couldn’t be said for their chances of success in the United States, however.

Because of the onstage bust-up and various other misdoings, The American Federation of Musicians refused to let the group tour the United States for the four years that followed the incident, a time when British music had stormed American shores courtesy of The Beatles. The group’s popularity in North America undoubtedly suffered as a result. As Davies plainly states, “In many respects, that ridiculous ban took away the best years of the Kinks’ career when the original band was performing at its peak.”

“We came about in the first days after Beatlemania, got chased everywhere we went and had to have police escorts to and fro,” Ray Davies told Wales Online in 2010. “I never even heard a note we played for a long time, the crowd’s screaming was always so loud.”

Perhaps tragically, but not uncommonly, the tension that drove much of The Kinks inter-personal relationships and music ended up being the very thing that would ultimately destroy the band.

“We were battlers,” Ray continues in the interview with Wales Online. “But the very thing that makes a band special is what ultimately causes it to break up. What made our music interesting ended up being the very thing that destroyed it.”
